awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research:  Institutional Change Through the End of Bretton Woods
awd_abstract_narration:
Throughout the postwar period, the Bretton Woods system secured stable exchange rates between international currencies by way of the U.S. dollar convertibility to gold at a set price. In 1971, the United States ceased this policy of gold-dollar convertibility, leaving the international economy governed by flexible exchange rates shortly thereafter. This project examines the process of international negotiation over monetary reform that culminated in unilateral American action in 1971, an outcome that defies existing understandings of how institutions change from within. The project also evaluates whether the end of Bretton Woods was driven more by international political interests than the imperatives of the international monetary system itself.  Findings will inform understanding of the relationship between economic crises and related political actions.

The project will analyze extensive archival records that document the decision-making process leading to the end of Bretton Woods. Using declassified documents from the National Archives in College Park, as well as several Presidential Libraries, the project will produce an updated historical narrative of the end of Bretton Woods. There are three objectives: 1) to extend the most current theories of institutional change to address the dynamics of policymaking processes; 2) to articulate a mechanism by which economic policy decisions capitalize on public perceptions of crisis; and 3) to contribute an update social science history of the end of Bretton Woods. These objectives will be reached through process-tracing to make causal inferences based on complex sequences of events.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This research has resulted in two scholarly publications in the past year, and a large body of archival data that the Co-PI is analyzing toward the publication of a book manuscript. The research informs contemporary world politics by examining the last major institutions of reconfiguration in global economic order. By analyzing the breakdown of the postwar international monetary system, the co-PI published an article in Politics & Society showing that the mechanisms of stability we typically ascribe to world-ordering institutions may actually create openings for powerful actors to dismantle them. The analysis used archival data gathered through the NSF DDIG, to show that suspending the international monetary system was never the preferred goal or strategy of the Nixon Administration in 1971, which had spent years preparing much more modest reforms. Nevertheless, U.S. policymakers took this unilateral action to dismantle the world's exchange rate system merely as a contingency plan to achieve a short-term goal. Surprisingly, the international institutions regulating this system did not channel U.S. action into a gradual evolution of the global economy, but rather gave way radically to the liberalized monetary regime that structures the world economy today.

            This explanation for the breakdown of the post-war Bretton Woods economic system represents a novel finding of great significance for our understanding of the contemporary global economy. Existing accounts identify critical pressure on the U.S. gold supply in 1971 as a determining economic force which necessitate the change. In contrast, the Co-PIs gathered evidence to demonstrate that the Nixon Administration strategically framed economic events as an urgent economic "crisis", deploying "crisis" as a justification. Nixon seized crisis opportunism to announce the policy change which had been decided upon significantly before the economic situation supposedly became critical. The Co-PIs apply these findings to contemporary issues of economic crisis, arguing that they should be viewed critically as objects of inquiry in their own right. This research was recently published by the Co-PIs in Socius.

            Aside from data gathered for the above two major research articles, the remainder of the data gathered under this grant examines U.S. policy responses to the shocks this major institutional displacement brought about. Major institutional changes followed this, including reforms to economic and social policy, particularly in developing countries, liberalization of capital markets globally, and liberalized rules on the rights of foreign investors. Most notably, the Co-PI has gathered data that shows the U.S. approach to reforming the International Monetary Fund (IMF) during the 1970s. The IMF is well known for its role in using credit to leverage major policy changes in indebted countries, particularly through structural adjustment programs. Criticism of these development policies has been harsh, but nevertheless its hallmark programs of austerity and deregulation have persisted as part of today's economic orthodoxy. The Co-PI connects knowledge from economic sociology to theories of power and property rights in order to explain the origin and persistence of these policies. His current work shows that U.S. strategy led to the creation of structural adjustment programs as a way to claim resources for multinational banks, whose foreign lending activities increased massively during the early 1970s.

            This research has been presented at several annual meetings of the American Sociological Association. It has been published in two articles. In addition, the Co-PI expect several additional articles and a book manuscript to result from the sum of this novel information.
